stem: A 16-year-old client with anorexia nervosa is undergoing an admission assessment. Based on the documentation in the Metabolic & Integumentary Stability Log, what is the best interpretation of the current physical findings?

options.text: The findings represent a compensatory metabolic shift due to severe starvation.
The acrocyanosis indicates an underlying congenital heart defect.
The lanugo hair is a sign of an endocrine tumor.
The hypothermia is caused by a primary infection.

rationale.correct: The physical findings of lanugo and acrocyanosis are classic physical compensations for severe starvation in anorexia nervosa. When there is no body fat left for insulation, the body grows fine, downy hair (lanugo) to try and trap heat. Acrocyanosis (blue extremities) and bradycardia occur as the body prioritizes blood flow to the core and slows down the metabolic 'engine' to prevent death. This is a compensatory metabolic shift rather than a primary heart or endocrine disease.
clinicalPearls: Lanugo is also seen in newborns (normal) but is a sign of extreme pathology in adults.
Acrocyanosis in anorexia is purely due to peripheral vasoconstriction to save core heat.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing acrocyanosis as a sign of heart failure.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: In anorexia, the heart *is* failing (atrophy), but acrocyanosis is a more specific sign of metabolic conservation (protecting the core temperature).

exhibits.title: Integumentary Assessment
exhibits.content:
Skin: Presence of fine, downy hair (lanugo) over the back and shoulders.
Extremities: Hands and feet are cold and appear bluish (acrocyanosis). Capillary refill 4 seconds.
Condition: Patient reports feeling 'freezing' even with three blankets.

exhibits.title: Physiological Reference
exhibits.content: In severe malnutrition, the body down-regulates its basal metabolic rate to conserve energy. This leads to hypothermia, bradycardia, and the growth of lanugo hair as an attempt to insulate the body.
